awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Elastocapillary fluid mechanics: spreading, splashing, and instability
awd_abstract_narration:
Liquid transport on soft surfaces such as human tissues, gels, or soft plastics occurs in nature, medical technologies, and industrial processes. Both the fluid and the surface may move and their motion is coupled.  This coupling makes prediction of the motion difficult and leads to new phenomena. In this work, liquid motion on soft substrates will be investigated by both theory and experiments through four research problems. The first research thrust relates to the surface-tension driven wave motion in liquids on soft solids, and is relevant to technologies such as inkjet printing and microfluidics.   The second area involves the motion of a drop on a soft surface due to gradients in the stiffness of the surface, and is relevant to the motion of cancer cells in human tissues.  The third investigation involves splashing of liquids on soft surfaces, and could impact forensic analysis and the aerosol delivery of drugs to neonates.  The final objective involves the spreading of liquids on deformable viscoelastic solids, and is applicable to the manufacture of flexible electronics and the design of biomedical devices.  The research is integrated with undergraduate education through long-term, focused projects and undergraduate summer research experiences, and with graduate education through curriculum development and graduate student research and mentoring activities.

The interaction of soft substrates with fluid interfaces is common to many biological, medical, and industrial processes; flexible electronics are manufactured using immersion lithography, ultrasonic waves are used for medical imaging of soft tissue interfaces, aerosol drug delivery for neonates suffering from respiratory distress syndrome as well as adults being treated for asthma and COPD relies upon droplet deposition on biological tissue, and forensic analysis interprets complex blood splat patterns. Describing these substrate deformations has led to the development of the field of elastocapillarity, in which elastic stresses are coupled to surface tension (capillarity). The aim of this CAREER award is to advance the field of elastocapillary fluid mechanics through carefully-selected theoretical and experimental studies of four canonical problems that focus on the dynamic coupling between the elastic and fluid fields: elastocapillary waves, droplet durotaxis, spreading on compliant substrates, and drop impact. Theoretical models will describe capillary instabilities in soft solids, Marangoni-driven flows that arise from gradients in substrate elasticity (durotaxis), and contact-line dynamics during spreading on compliant substrates. Table-top experiments on drop impact will be designed to facilitate undergraduate learning through research. Elastocapillarity is a new, interdisciplinary field that encompasses a wide range of traditional disciplines, such as fluid mechanics, solid mechanics, and mathematics. The lack of a well-developed course curriculum and a continuously evolving subject matter requires innovative strategies to educate students in this emerging interdisciplinary field, broadly categorized as "learning through research", which incorporate focused long-term Creative Inquiry projects and summer research opportunities. Delivering educational content via targeted extended research projects can serve as a template for other emerging scientific fields. Targeted mentoring through the graduate research and professional development seminar series will improve research culture and help place under-represented students in academic/scientific careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rigid solids can take on largely any shape as the undeformed configuration is a minimum of the elastic energy, whereas liquids, due to capillarity, tend to a spherical shape in order to minimize surface energy. Soft solids, such as gels and biological tissues, can have elastic and surface energies that are of the same order of magnitude, giving rise to many new and unexpected elastocapillary phenomena, which can occur in two-phase systems (soft solid-gas) or three-phase systems (soft solid-liquid-gas). In this award, the PI used theoretical and experimental techniques to investigate dynamic elastocapillary phenomena, focusing on four canonical problems: 1) elastocapillary waves, 2) droplet durotaxis, 3) spreading on soft substrates, and 4) drop impact on soft substrates. During this project, several intellectual contributions were made in the broad areas of interfacial instability and soft matter.

Intellectual merit: Soft interfaces can reconfigure dynamically resulting in the formation of oscillatory surface waves or irrecoverable deformation, i.e. instability. Dynamic stability analysis has been used to predict information about the resulting pattern formation through identification of the dominant or fastest growing mode and compared with related experiments. Here, both surface tension and viscoelasticity affect wavenumber selection in a number of dynamic pattern formation phenomena in soft solids, such as elasto-capillary-gravity waves, Rayleigh-Taylor instability, Plateau-Rayleigh instability, Faraday waves, and drop oscillations, all of which have direct analogues with classical hydrodynamic instabilities helping to interpret the relevant physics. In all cases, there is a transition from solid-like to liquid-like behavior at a critical elastocapillary number. A drop vibration rheometer has been proposed which utilizes the frequency response curve of an ultrasonically-levitated drop to measure the surface tension, elasticity, and viscosity of a soft solid, which is something that has been notoriously difficult to do using existing measurement techniques, such as the Wilhelmy plate or pendant drop methods.

Liquid surface tension can deform the soft substrate upon which it rests into a wetting ridge at the three-phase contact-line and this can affect droplet spreading on a finite thickness substrate and cause spontaneous droplet motion on a substrate with thickness gradient. Mathematical models have been developed to understand the dynamics of drop motion on soft substrates, which couples the velocity field in the fluid domain to the deformation field in the solid domain through the deformable liquid-solid boundary. On a substrate with thickness gradient, an asymmetry in the contact-angle induces a net force that causes droplet motion with velocity predicted using a self-consistent computational approach by balancing the power dissipated in the viscoelastic substate to the power associated with the wetting force. Lubrication theory has been applied to a spreading drop to predict enhanced spreading rates on soft substrates, when compared against classical results for drop spreading on rigid substrates. Experimental studies of drop impact onto soft elastic substrates have quantified the splash threshold, splash spine number, spreading factor, and retraction factor during droplet spreading. These results show that it is harder to splash on soft substrates as some of the impact energy is transformed into substrate deformation. 

Broader impacts: This project has resulted in numerous broader impacts. Firstly, the interaction of soft substrates with fluid interfaces is common to many biological, medical, and industrial processes; flexible electronics are manufactured using immersion lithography, ultrasonic waves are used for medical imaging of soft tissue interfaces, aerosol drug delivery for neonates suffering from respiratory distress syndrome as well as adults being treated for asthma and COPD relies upon droplet deposition on biological tissue, and forensic analysis interprets complex blood splat patterns. The fundamental results generated by this project are highly relevant to the aforementioned technologies. To educate undergraduate students in this multidisciplinary field has required innovative strategies which are research-focused, including long-term focused Creative Inquiry projects and summer research opportunities. Delivering educational content via targeted extended research projects can serve as a template for other emerging scientific fields. Graduate students have gained valuable mentoring experience through these programs. This approach has resulted in numerous award winning entries to the Science as Art program at Clemson University and the APS DFD Gallery of Fluid motion, both of which are venues that highlight the aesthetic beauty of science to the broader public. Lastly, the PI has founded the graduate student research (GSR) seminar series to serve as a forum for graduate students to disseminate their research results to their peers so as to foster interdisciplinary collaboration and create a sense of camaraderie in the department associated with a thriving scientific environment.
